title.narrative: Support to technical and vocational training for Liberia#s youth

description.narrative: Liberia’s youth constitutes nearly half of the Liberian labour force but is exposed to high unemployment, underemployment and vulnerable employment rates. The global commodity prices crisis, combined with the effects of the Ebola crisis, have devastated the Liberian economy and worsened youth’s fragility problems. A socially and economically marginalised young population can pose serious risks to national security, social cohesion and stability. Liberian youth generally lack employable skills and are ill-equipped to access new economic opportunities. Efforts to improve their employability are constrained by a Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) TVET sector characterised by serious shortcomings in terms of quality and relevance, access and equity, funding, and governance. The Government of Liberia (GoL) recognises that the transition towards inclusive growth will not happen unless human capabilities are enhanced and the quality of education and vocational training are improved to match the demands of the labour market. The present intervention will seek to strengthen the Liberian TVET sector in its capacity to deliver equitable and gender-balanced access to high-quality and demand-driven TVET. This will be done by supporting capacity development at central and TVET provider level, and by strengthening links with the private sector. The intervention will address equity issues with emphasis on remote South East rural areas and vulnerable youth, including people with disabilities.

participating-org.narrative: Trust Fund for Increased Food Security through Agribusiness

title.narrative: Promoting social stabilization through vocational training and job creation for vulnerable people and communities in post-Ebola Liberia

description.narrative:
While Liberia is still on the way to recovery from the civil wars between 1989 and 2003, the recent outbreak of Ebola has seriously affected their path for recovery in an already fragile post-conflict setting putting a tremendous burden on the Government of Liberia.
Liberia heavily depends on the transnational corporations (TNCs) and their exports of rubber, iron ore and oil palm for growth, employment and fiscal revenues. Due to the plunge in the prices of these export commodities since 2014 and also unhealthy global economic environment, ArcelorMittal has laid off over 450 employees since January 2016, while the Putu Iron Ore Mining Company has reportedly shutdown and left. The rubber plantations put thousands of Liberians out of jobs and closed schools and hospitals run by them. However; Liberia does not have any other productive sector that can cushion these negative socio-economic impacts.
The proposed project aims to promote social stabilization by improving human security of the vulnerable people and communities affected by crises through promoting wood furniture industry and providing vocational skills to unemployed youth in close coordination with transnational corporations (TNCs).

title.narrative: Increasing Sierra Leone#s competitiveness through enhanced productivity and trade compliance in selected value chains

description.narrative:
The overall objective of the programme is to "strengthen the competitiveness of Sierra Leone and enhance the country's integration into the regional and international trading system". The specific objectives are: 1. To improve the performance, growth and contribution to industry, regional trade and exports of selected value chains (VCs). 2. To improve the climate for business at national level.
The focus will be on interventions for the development and enhanced competitiveness for cocoa, cassava and oil palm with strong potential for regional and global value chains, job creation and growth through regional value chain linkages. However, a market driven and flexible approach will be embedded in the project interventions such that other value chains can benefit from the project activities and outputs. The targeting of the selected product lines is consistent with the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) regional industrialisation priorities for agro-industries. In particular, this initiative is in line with the value-added transformation of local raw materials, increasing the industrial sector’s percentage of the GDP, contributing to increasing the share of industrial products in regional trade and the drive to increase industrial products from West Africa to the world market. This approach is consistent with the multi-sectoral investment programme led by the Government focusing, amongst others, on private sector development to drive socio-economic transformation in the aftermath of Ebola and falling iron prices. The Ministries in charge of Trade, Industry and Agriculture are working to increase competitiveness of 1 000 SMEs to add value and find new markets for farm products, to ensure diversification of economic activities and avoid falling in the trap of an exclusively mineral based economy. Ensuring equal access of female and male entrepreneurs to the benefits of this national policy will be key for its success.

The government of Guinea in its National Economic and Social Development Plan (PNDES) 2016-2020 placed industrial development as central instrument to accelerate its economic diversification and structural transformation for inclusive and sustainable development. The PNDES is structures in four pillars and sectoral and cross-sectoral strategic programmes and projects. The UNIDO Cooperation Framework (Country Programme) has been identified in the PNDES as one of the PNDES underlying strategic programme. In that regard, UNIDO was requested in 2018 by the Government through the Ministry of Industry to support in the development and implementation of a Country Programme that match the post-EBOLA recovery context around the PNDES and the UNDAF 2018-2022. Following the request of the Government of the Republic of Guinea, and a series of consultations between the Government and UNIDO in 2017-2018, the parties agreed to develop jointly a new technical cooperation framework in the form of a country programme. Aligned to the renewed UNIDO ISID mandate, the CP focuses on autonomous but flexible components in order to: (I) Respond to changes that may occur during the operationalization of the country programme; (ii) Facilitate the mobilization of funds and (iii) Promote more efficient implementation. This CP focuses on UNIDO specific contributions to Guinea national development framework by aligning with national priorities as defined by the PNDES, the UNDAF (2018-2022), the document "Guinea, Vision 2040" and the National Policy Letter of Small and Medium Enterprises (LPN / SME). Otherwise, this Country Programme is also part of the reference framework for the implementation of UNIDO strategy and operational plan for Least Developed Countries (LDCs) over the 2012-2020 period. The current CP framework developed through a participative process led by a national committee led by the office of the Prime Minister and the Ministry of Industry. The CP estimated at budget 21,950,000 $US, is structured into on five (5) components: • Component 1: Development of selected value chains and agro-industry. • Component 2: Industrial competitiveness and SME development. • Component 3: Strengthen the employability and entrepreneurial capacities of young people and women. • Component 4: Promotion of clean energies, industrial efficiency and good practices. • Component 5: Mobilization and coordination of partnerships for inclusive and sustainable industrial development.

title.narrative: Democratic Republic of Congo - CBPF Management Unit
Democratic Republic of Congo - CBPF Management Unit

description.narrative: Le BCAH coordonne les interventions d’urgence au niveau mondial pour sauver des vies et protéger les populations en cas de crise humanitaire. Nous plaidons pour une action humanitaire efficace et raisonnée, par tous et pour tous

The humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) remains precarious and extremely fluid. This is principally a result of continuing conflicts between communities, between non-state armed groups and Congolese security forces, and due to prevailing socio-economic challenges that affect the most vulnerable Congolese. An estimated 12.8 people are in need of humanitarian assistance and protection in 2019: this figure represents 10 per cent of the total worldwide humanitarian caseload. Those affected by this complex and widespread crisis remain exposed to pervasive human rights violations, especially sexual and gender-based violence, chronic malnutrition, and epidemics, notably cholera, measles, and the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD). Insecurity has had a devastating impact on people’s capacity to access food, and 12.8 million people across the DRC are facing severe food insecurity. The situation is further complicated by political uncertainty and economic downturn.

Upgrading Water and Sanitation Systems Incorporating Skills-Based Training and Employment for Youth in Eloba-Affected Slum Communities

description.narrative: This project proposal is pursuant to the need to expand basic sanitation, improve environmental conditions and hygiene, and promote youth employment in the slum communities of Monrovia. The proposal is made as an urgent component of the UN’s overall support to the implementation of the post-Ebola recovery strategy in Liberia. The project will constitute the first phase of a long term slum upgrading programme, which will help to strengthen resilience, and reduce vulnerability to Ebola outbreaks and other public health disasters in the urban areas of Liberia. The project has been conceived within the framework of the Joint UN programming approach with UN-Habitat, UNICEF and ILO as the main UN partners to collaborate with GoL partners, including the Ministry of Public Works, the Ministry of Health & Social Welfare, the Ministry of Gender and Social Development, the Monrovia City Corporation (MCC) and the Liberia Water and Sewerage Corporation (LWSC). The project will employ the labor-intensive approach to implement the solid waste management component of the intervention. In addition, it will help build the capacity of Community Based Enterprises that will be responsible for environmental sanitation. By using this strategy, the project will not only contribute to local economic development in the project area, but will as well help ensure to some degree sustainability of the project. With regards the skills training component, established vocational centers in the project area will be engaged to conduct these training with technical supervision and support from the ILO.

description.narrative: L'impact de la MVE va au-delà de la santé et touche tous les secteurs de la société, entrave la fourniture des services sociaux de base et compromet la cohésion sociale. Les écoles publiques et privées ainsi que les universités dans les localités touchées n'ont pas commencé l'année scolaire aux dates prévues par le Ministère de l'Enseignement Primaire Secondaire et Professionnel), et bien que les alternatives en matière d'éducation soient en cours de développement il n'y a pas de calendrier clair pour ces écoles dont le fonctionnement est toujours perturbé par des évènements critiques.

title.narrative: Sierra Leone: West Africa Competitiveness Programme

description.narrative: The project aims to enhance the competitiveness of the cocoa, palm oil and cassava sectors in Sierra Leone in order to boost the country's connection to regional and global value chains, create more jobs and strengthen its resilience against economic chocs. A market driven and flexible approach will be embedded in the project interventions such that other value chains can benefit from the project activities and outputs. This approach is consistent with the multi-sectoral investment programme led by the Government focusing, amongst others, on private sector development to drive socio-economic transformation in the aftermath of Ebola and falling iron prices. The Ministries in charge of Trade, Industry and Agriculture, our main partners, are working to increase the competitiveness of 1000 SMEs to add value and find new markets for farm products, to ensure diversification of economic activities and avoid falling in the trap of an exclusively mineral based economy. Ensuring equal access of female and male entrepreneurs to the benefits of this national policy will be key for its success.

title.narrative: Enhancing Integrated Capacity and Assistance to Crisis Affected Populations on Disease Outbreaks, Natural Disasters and Returns in Burundi

description.narrative: This project's aim is to contribute to the national and local efforts undertaken to prevent and respond to potential disease outbreaks and natural disasters and to reintegrate displaced populations within communities. The project specifically aims to address three primary and urgent crises in Burundi that have intensified since April of 2018: 1) an ebola virus disease outbreak in neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo that has the potential to spread to Burundi as well as an active cholera outbreak that started in December; 2) extreme flooding and mudslides due to torrential rains that have ravaged parts of the country and 3) gaps associated with the absorption of the return of tens of thousands of Burundians who were living in the United Republic of Tanzania, which poses a potential threat to Burundi’s stability.

title.narrative: Direct Life-Saving and Protection Assistance for Conflict-Affected Populations in Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

description.narrative: The ongoing violence and inter-community tensions continue to cause massive displacements especially in Ituri province and an increase in the number of people without access to basic services, coupled with the continued Ebola Viruses Disease outbreak in Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and recently the COVID-19 pandemic, has placed significant pressure on the provision of and need for humanitarian assistance in eastern DRC (North Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika Provinces). Under this project, the International Organization for Migration will directly contribute to improving the living conditions of conflict-affected internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the targeted areas; strengthening accountable service delivery for IDPs and increase affected populations’ resilience to withstand future humanitarian emergency situations.

title.narrative: Emergency Grant Aid in Response to the Ebola Virus Disease Outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description.narrative: The project aims to support national efforts in responding to the on-going ebola epidemics (9th and 10th) in the Democratic Republic of Congo while strengthening national capacity to better prevent, detect and respond to public health emergencies in the future. The project is aligned with the National Response Plan (May 2018), World Health Organization's (WHO) Strategic Response Plan (May 2018) and the recommendations from the Joint External Evaluation (JEE) on the implementation of the International Health Regulations (IHR) conducted in March 2018. The project will focus on strengthening surveillance at point of entries and at important congregation points, cross border coordination and technical and operational support for contingency planning specifically as it relates to capacity building of International Health Regulations (2005) core capacities.

title.narrative: Assessing Population Mobility Dynamics and Patterns To Strengthen the Ebola Virus Disease Readiness Activities in Burundi

description.narrative: The project adheres to CERF's lifesaving criteria through risk mapping and data sharing to reduce the risk of cross-border ebola virus disease (EVD) transmission. Availability of data on cross-border population mobility pathways obtained through population mobility mapping (PMM) and flow monitoring in four high-risk provinces will facilitate coordination and rapid information sharing internally with partners in Burundi, and will inform public health decisions aiming to prevent, detect and respond to EVD.

mailing-address.narrative: Burundi, Burundi

title.narrative: Improving National Preparedness and Information Management for Ebola Virus Disease Surveillance at Ugandan Points of Entry

description.narrative: IOM will support national efforts to strengthen capacity to implement the international health regulations to better prevent, detect and respond to the ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreak and other public health emergencies in Uganda at points of entries in Kisoro, Kanungu, Rubirizi and Rukungiri with a human mobility perspective. Specifically, IOM will support preparedness at points of entry (POEs) and will contribute to the overall coordination on surveillance under the leadership of the Ministry of Health and World Health Organization through a three-prolonged approach: improved targeting of national preparedness and public health response strategies with comprehensive population mobility-related information; enhanced national and local capacity at POEs to effectively prevent, detect and manage EVD through training for border and health personnel, screening and surveillance; and strengthened capacities to raise alerts and improve reaction to possible threats across the border through improved POE coordination.

title.narrative: Strengthening Ebola Response and Preparedness at Point of Entries and Point of Control in Democratic Republic of Congo

description.narrative: Strengthening Ebola response and preparedness at points of entry (PoE) and points of sanitary control (PoC) in DRC. The proposed approach focuses on the four following outcomes: Strengthening PoE/PoC human resources and logistic capacities (I), improving coordination of activities and related information management (II), enhancing surveillance efforts and access to basic services (III), as well as investing in preparedness in non-affected health zones and provinces (IV).

title.narrative: Improving National Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and COVID-19 Outbreaks and Pandemic Preparedness and Surveillance Measures in Rwanda

description.narrative: IOM will conduct population mobility mapping (PMM) exercise at the points of entries in the selected high-risk district to enable better understanding of the mobility dynamics in the country at the borders with DRC and Burundi. IOM will also conduct flow monitoring, which tracks movement flows and the overall situation at key, high-mobility locations. Through this component, IOM will build the capacities of the government institutions working at the border (i.e. frontline workers), to develop and ensure sustainability of the PMM intervention, the first of its kind in Rwanda. In addition, IOM will provide capacity building support to Ministry of Health providing incentives to its specialised frontline workers to ensure continuity of active surveillance including screening migrants crossing the borders.

title.narrative: Response to Ebola Virus Disease Epidemic in North Kivu and Ituri Provinces

description.narrative: To improve the collective response to the Ebola epidemic, IOM intends to strengthen and expand its current operations in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, in line with the latest Strategic Response Plan (SRP4). The proposed approach focuses on four interventions that will be implemented. The first will be strengthening the functionality and quality of points of entry (PoE) / points of control (PoC) health screening services, including screening 24/7 a week at strategic PoE / PoC level. The second will be to improve contact tracing and referral mechanisms at priority PoE / PoC; 3. The third will be strengthening cross-border coordination, participatory mobility mapping and population flow monitoring. Lastly, the project will focus on strengthening disease prevention activities at PoE / PoC through risk communication and community engagement activities. The proposed activities have an immediate impact on the health of the Congolese population and neighboring countries in line to the response to the Ebola Virus Disease outbreak.

title.narrative: Strengthening Disease Prevention and Surveillance at Points of Entry and Points of Control in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

description.narrative: This project contributes to the interruption of disease transmission by reinforcing Ebola virus disease surveillance and prevention activities at points of entry (PoE) and points of control (PoC) through improved management of PoE/PoC operations. It is estimated that this project will support a total of 90 PoE/PoC (80 existing PoE/PoC and 10 new ones). The proposed project will prioritize strengthening disease surveillance and prevention at PoE/PoC that are epidemiologically critical, using available data pertaining to transmission trends, mobility routes, and population flows associated with the current Ebola virus epidemic in the Democratic Repulic of Congo.

The programme will also enhance the capacity of immigration officials and strengthen facilities in points of entry with DRC to adequately manage large cross-border flow by empowering selected border posts with essential equipment and infrastructure rehabilitation.

title.narrative: National and Community Capacity Strengthening to Enhance Prevention and Response to Emerging Health Threats in Burundi

description.narrative: The project will contribute to the national and local efforts undertaken in the response to potential disease outbreaks, particularly in light of the ongoing Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) epidemic and COVID-19 in the neighboring DRC, as well as national disasters in Burundi in terms of health and border management capacities at the national and subnational levels. The project will support the Ministry of Health at the national level through procurement equipment and material to facilitate and strengthen surveillance and oversight for EVD preparedness. The project will also provide the Ministry of Security and Disaster Management, specifically the immigration department in charge of border management, with essential equipment to strengthen and facilitate border management coordination between the central and the local levels and reinforce the level of the preparedness against EVD and other communicable diseases.

title.narrative: Response to the Ebola Virus Disease Epidemic in the Nzérékoré Region

description.narrative: The project, in line with the Government's priorities within the framework of the National Response Plan, aims to contribute to the interruption of the chain of transmission of EVD in the Nzérékoré region by directing the response towards the target areas presenting high risks linked to the dynamics of mobility. The response strategy will focus on the current epicenter and the surrounding health districts of the N'Zérékoré region and will ensure points of entry and health control points capacity improving around the epicente, active search for contacts and suspected cases along the axes of mobility and support to public health information and cross-border management of health emergencies.

title.narrative: Enhancing the Safety of World Health Organization (WHO) Personnel in Ebola Response with Security Communications and Analysis Network (SCAAN)

description.narrative: The Security Communications and Analysis Network (SCAAN) is a personnel security tool that uses modern communication and technology to provide personnel with real-time information on emerging threats, facilitate headcounts, and empower personnel to be in instant contact with securitypersonnel in an emergency. Developed by and for IOM personnel, the network has attracted interest and attention of UN and international organizations for its potential to save lives, particularly the World Health Organization (WHO) as they scale up to respond to the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).This project will allow for an inception phase of SCAAN by WHO personnel working in the Ebola response to enhance their security and WHO's duty of care.

title.narrative: Enhancement and qualification of Nigeria to independently prevent and cope with crises due to epidemic threats
Ertüchtigung und Befähigung Nigerias zu eigenständiger Prävention und Bewältigung von Krisen durch epidemische Gefahren

description.narrative: The aim of the project is to set up a modern isolation unit for highly contagious patients (e.g. for Lassa and Ebola fever), which will also enable doctors and nurses to be trained in the safe handling of these patients and to ensure rapid diagnostics and sample storage in a biobank at the Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH), Edo State, Nigeria. The ISTH diagnoses and treats the majority of Lassa fever patients in West Africa and has developed into a training centre for the entire region. The establishment of a modern isolation unit would be a "lighthouse" for the region.

Ziel des Projektes ist der Aufbau einer modernen Isoliereinheit für hochkontagiöse Patienten (z.B. für Lassa und Ebola Fieber), die auch eine Ausbildung von Ärzten und Schwestern im sicheren Umgang mit diesen Patienten ermöglicht sowie Sicherstellung einer schnellen Diagnostik und Probenlagerung in einer Biobank am Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH), Edo State, Nigeria. Das ISTH diagnostiziert und behandelt die meisten Lassa-Fieber Patienten in Westafrika und hat sich zu einem Ausbildungszentrum für die ganze Region entwickelt. Der Aufbau einer modernen Isoliereinheit hätte für die Region "Leuchtturm" Charakter.

title.narrative: Access to Sanitation, Water and Hygiene

description.narrative: The programme will promote sustained use of safe water supplies and sanitation services, and sustained adoption of hygiene practices in targeted areas (see below), including in fragile countries. It will focus on poor and vulnerable people, and on women and girls. The program contributes to improved health (e.g. by preventing cholera diseases), improved nutrition and well being of the targeted people. It also aims to positively contribute to a reduction of “children on the move” (Migration along the entire migration route). This programme is the follow-up of the succesful Dutch funded ASWA WCA programme in nine West- and Central African countries. (For six countries this program ended in 2017. It still runs in Guinee, Sierra Leone, Liberia – countries that were struck by Ebola, and where the development program was suspended consequently. For these countries the program will end in 2019.) As to the IOB evaluation (2012-2015) regarding Dutch cooperation with the UN development system the former UNICEF ASWA WCA programme has substantially contributed to the Dutch goals for drinking water and sanitation. The new ASWA II NL programme will build on its experience and lessons learnt form the previous program (see 2.2.1) in providing equitable access to WASH and will therefore (a) shift its focus to strenghtening sector systems to sustain outcomes; (b) shift towards a more integrated approach to WASH access at community level; (c) shift from a project approach towards sector wide approach in terms of the sustainability framework, and (d) consolidate implementation models to develop an investment case/financing plan for rural WASH.

title.narrative: ACC POWER Promotion of Women Empow.

description.narrative: ACC Promotion of Women Empowerment and Rights Project - Background and Problem analysis Sierra Leone as a post-conflict, fragile state with 77% of its population living below the poverty started several years of robust e conomic growth as new mining activity came on stream in 2011. Since the discovery of iron ore in 2011, the mining sector had been the main driver of growth, resulting in an unprecedented growth rate of 21% in 2013. In May 2014, Sierra Leone faced an outbreak of the Ebola virus epidemic. The effect of the twin shocks in 2014 (the Ebola outbreak and sharp drop in iron ore prices) have dealt a severe blow to Sierra Leone’s economy by prompting a sharp slump in activity with grave economic downturn. The impact of the twin shocks on the economy and safeguard sustainability was gravely felt by the majority of the poor who are smallholder. The effect was felt beyond the mining area in the Northern Province to Bo District in the Southern Province of Sierra Leone. Bo is the second most populous District in Sierra Leone (after the Western Area Urban District). The ripple effect of the twin shocks set in motion harsh trend on the gender inequality especially with rural women. Rural women in the environs of Bo district are affected by poverty and inequalities. They do not have economic security due to diminishing access to land, less property rights, and their inability to access services, such as extension and credit. Illiteracy, combined with an ingrained sense of stereotypical roles and responsibilities have left many women without the confidence to become leaders or involved in governance. Harmful traditional practices, such as early marriage, Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) and secret societies increase the vulnerability of women and contribute to their discrimination Most men continue to undermine the efforts and potentials of women despite the fact that female-headed households are doing better than male-headed households with 61.4% of male-headed households below the poverty line compared to 57.1% of female-headed households (World Bank Poverty Profile, 2013). Yet, patriarchal structures exclude women from decision-making and leadership positions at all levels. Intervention Empowering women economically is necessary to enable them build resources base to influence decision making at all levels. This will be pursued under two components: Livelihood and Income Generation. Solidaridad will work with already identified women groups to develop sustainable livelihood opportunities including vegetable gardening, swamp development to enhance food security and increase their ability to manage livelihood options. The project will provide training, improved food crop and vegetable seeds, simple farming tools and technical support to promote sustainable livelihood opportunities for rural women. The project will work with 200 women and young girls who are either school dropouts or did not have opportunity to attend school. The project will mobilize and train over 200 women using the Stimulate, Assess, Listen and Learn and Transfer (SALT) and Gender Model Family (GMF) approach to engender social and behavioural change for them to realize the available assets and potential in their communities. This will precede the introduction of Village Savings and Loan Associations (VSLAs) which seeks to organize women into groups, train and provide them with tool kits to start local savings culture. Within six months of savings, these women can begin to access loans from the fund to start businesses, pay bills or invest in vegetable production. The women group leaders will be trained on business development; entrepreneurship <(>&<)> small business management, leadership and group management to enable them gain both hard and soft skills to man

description.narrative: World Press Photo tentoonstelling met randprogram-mering KSS organiseert in September 2019 voor de tweede keer een World Press Photo tentoonstelling. In de tentoonstelling zijn dit jaar twee prijswinnende fotoseries over de DRC op-genomen; een eerste over de ebola-uitbraak in Oost-DRC, de tweede over de politieke protesten die in de hoofdstad Kinshasa plaatsvonden in de aanloop naar de verkiezingen van afgelopen december. Diverse activiteiten rondom de tentoonstelling zullen diep-gang geven aan het evenement en zijn een buitenkans voor KNL om kernwaarden als persvrijheid, toegang tot informa-tie, demonstratierecht, cultuurdiplomatie en mensenrech-ten in het algemeen te promoten. Da arnaast speelt KNL zich met deze activiteit bij een groot en gemêleerd publiek in de kijker als voorvechter van deze waarden. De randprogrammering zal bestaan uit; - Een panelgesprek tijdens de openingsceremonie waarin o.a. WPP-fotograaf John Wessels, Nationale Commissie voor Mensenrechten en de Ministeries voor Mensenrechten en Justitie met elkaar in ge-sprek gaan over persvrijheid, toegang tot informatie en demonstratierecht en de foto’s van de DRC in de tentoonstelling. - Persvoorlichting waarin KSS en John Wessels aan ge-schreven media, online media en radio en televisie de tentoonstelling introduceren. KNLs inzet in pro-motie van democratische waarden en mensenrech-ten zal aan bod komen. - Masterclass journalistieke fotografie voor 15 jonge fotografen waarin zowel praktische vaardigheden als rechten en plichten van journalisten aan bod komen. De tentoonstelling vindt plaats in de open lucht, op een druk plein waar veel verkeer, voetgangers en openbaar vervoer passagiers passeren. Het publiek dat toegang heeft tot deze tentoonstelling is dus zeer groot en breed. (Nb Dit bemo betreft aanvraag voor de productie van de tentoonstelling en alle randprogrammering. De kosten voor de WPP-tentoonstellingsrechten en WPP ondersteuning zijn op een ander budget verhaald).

description.narrative: Immediate Trade and Working Capital Relief: Through increased access to finance, the Facility will contribute to maintaining trade flows for basic and essential goods across key economic sectors (manufacturing, agri, energy) in the three countries severely affected by the Ebola outbreak. Improved availability of credit to these sectors is expected to benefit basic-good producers and importers, among others along the value chain, and therefore alleviate economic impact, sustain employment and maintain livelihoods. Demonstration Effect in FCS/IDA Countries: The Facility is expected to send a positive signal to the international community about IFC''s commitment to these fragile economies and will encourage other foreign institutions to follow.

The proposed project, Ebola Emergency Liquidity Facility (EELF) is IFCs immediate response to the ongoing Ebola outbreak in West Africa and is targeting Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, the countries severely affected to date. It seeks to provide immediate private sector-focused support to help alleviate the immediate trade and foreign currency denominated working capital needs in the countries. IFCs immediate intervention relies on the use of IFCs Financial Institutions Group (FIG) platforms to quickly help clients with working capital and contribute to maintaining trade flows, supporting employment, and restoring supplies of key goods and services. This intervention is the first stage of a more comprehensive, cross-sector (FIG, MAS, and Infra) combined IS-AS response. EELFs total size is up to US$75 million for IFCs own account and would comprise discrete funding lines to each eligible bank in the three targeted countries. The tenor of each facility is up to 12 months, with renewable options. EELF will initially target existing IFC portfolio clients in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone and will later be also made available to other banks operating in West Africa.

title.narrative: Summary of Investment Information - Anticipated Impact Measurement & Monitoring (AIMM) Assessment and Main Environmental & Social Risks and Impacts of the Project

description.narrative: The Project has substantial develop impact in terms of the following: (i) Farmer Benefits: Through this Project, farmers will be able to receive soft credit in the form of fertilizers and agro-chemicals to improve yields; expected to increase to from 1375 kgs per hectare to 1750 kgs per hectare.in 5 years; reach 7,500 farmers by 2019; increase awareness at the farmer level of pest management and effective management of agrochemicals though the extension services and training on cocoa agronomy provided by Wienco Liberia; (ii) Alleviate Effects of Ebola Crisis: This Project will support the cocoa industry in Liberia at a moment when many Liberians' source of income has been threatened by the spread of Ebola and will contribute to the long-term sustainability of the sector, and Liberia's economic recovery post-Ebola; (iii) Create Jobs: This project will favor local job creation with an incremental 73 permanent positions by 2019; (iv) Improve E&S Practices: This Project will help the Company improve its Environmental and Social standards; and (v) Positive Demonstration Effect: IFC's investment in Liberia will send a positive signal to international markets about IFC's commitment to these fragile economies and will encourage other investors to follow. In addition, IFC can play a catalytic role in market development by bringing other participants to the countries to augment IFC's crisis response efforts.

Wienco Liberia Limited (the Company or Wienco Liberia) was established in 2011 and is engaged in the import and distribution of high quality fertilizers and crop protection products for cocoa trees in Liberia, as well as the purchase and export of dry cocoa beans from smallholder farmers. The Company is located at Monrovia with offices in Bong, Nimba and Lofa counties. Supported by training, innovation and product development, Wienco Liberia is partnering with farmer associations to provide affordable agricultural inputs to farmers on a reliable, timely and efficient basis so to improve productivity of smallholder farmers in Liberia and increase their incomes. Input packages are given by Wienco Liberia to farmers as credit facilities whereby repayment from farmer groups is received after the harvest seasons. In order to further increase cocoa yields and reach more farmers, Wienco Liberia requires funding for capital expenditure and pre-harvest financing of agricultural inputs for cocoa (the Project).

Samuel Oduro-Asare Wienco Liberia Limited PO Box 1998, 1000 Monrovia 10, Liberia Cell phone: (+231)(0)880845440 mailto:s.asare@wiencoliberia.com Website: http://www.wienco.com
Wienco Liberia Limited PO Box 1998, 1000 Monrovia 10, Liberia

name.narrative: Wienco Liberia is partnering with Cocoa Lela Association (CLA), a non-profit organization established in 2011, to increase its provision of fertilizers and crop protection products to cocoa farmers within the association. CLA is located in Gbarnga in Bong County of Liberia which is a key cocoa growing area. The Association also operates in three cocoa growing counties (Bong, Lofa and Nimba) in up-country Liberia. The financing plan of capital expenditure is to build about 6 warehouses in 5 counties in Liberia for the storage of cocoa beans and agro-inputs in order to strengthen cocoa beans collection from farmers as well as Wienco Liberias distribution system of agro-inputs.

description.narrative: The project aims to establish a new plant-based current Good Manufacturing Practice (cGMP)-level manufacturing facility together with related processing laboratories and climate-controlled hydroponic grow rooms to produce reagents for the testing and treatment of COVID-19 and other endemic African diseases (e.g. Ebola, dengue, measles, HIV or yellow fever) in Mauritius. The facility is expected to reach a production capacity equivalent to 100 million test kits and/or vaccines per month.
